fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An algebraic (equational) theory T = (\Sigma _T, E_T) is given by a signature \Sigma _T and a collection \Epsilon _T of equations over the terms of this signature.
Notes about algebraic effects and handlers.
In algebra we study mathematical structures that are equipped with operations satisfying equational laws.

A signature \Sigma is a collection of operation symbols with arities \{(\text {op}_i, \text {ar}_i)\}_i. The operation symbols opi may be any anything, but are usually thought of as syntactic entities, while arities \text {ar}_i are non-negative integers. An operation symbol whose arity is 0 is called a constant or a nullary symbol. Operation symbols with arities 1, 2 and 3 are referred to as unary, binary, and ternary, respectively.

A list of distinct variables x_1, \cdots , c_k is called a context. The \Sigma \text {-terms} in this context are built inductively using the following rules:
Each variable x_i is a \Sigma \text {-term} in this context
If t_1, \cdots , t_{\text {ar}_i} are \Sigma \text {-terms} in this context, then \text {op}_i(t_1, \cdots , t_{\text {ar}_i}) is a \Sigma \text {-term} in this context We write x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid t to indicate that t is a \Sigma \text {-term} in the context x_1, \cdots , x_k. A closed \Sigma \text {-term} is a term in the empty context.
A \Sigma \text {-equation} is a pair of \Sigma \text {-terms} l and r in the context x_1, \cdots , x_k: x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid l = r We shall often elide the context and write simply l = r.
An algebraic (equational) theory T = (\Sigma _T, E_T) is given by a signature \Sigma _T and a collection \Epsilon _T of equations over the terms of this signature.

Let \Sigma be a signature, an interpretation I of \Sigma is given by the following data:
A set |I| called the carrier of the interpretation
For each operation symbol \text {op}_i, a map [\text {op}_i]_I : |I|^i \to |I| The bracket []_I here is called the semantic bracket and is typically used when syntactic entities (operation symbols, terms, equations) are mapped to their mathematical counterparts.

The interpretation can be extended to terms and equations. A \Sigma \text {-term} t in the context x_1, \cdots , x_k is interpreted as a function [x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid t]_I : |I|^k \to |I| as follows:
The variable x_i is interpreted as the i-th projection [x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid x_i]_I : |I|^k \to |I|, \quad (a_1, \cdots , a_k) \mapsto a_i
A compound term in context x_1, \cdots , x_k is interpreted as the composition of the semantic brackets of the operation symbols and the terms: |I|^k \xrightarrow {[t_1]_I, \cdots , [t_{\text {ar}_i}]_I} |I|^{\text {ar}_i} \xrightarrow {[\text {op}_i]_I} |I|

A model M of an algebraic theory T is an interpretation of the signature \Sigma _T which validates all the equations E_T. That is, for each equations x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid l = r in E_T, we have: [x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid l]_M = [x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid r]_M We refer to a model of T as a T\text {-algebra} or T\text {-model}.

Let M and N be models of an algebraic theory T. A T-homomorphism from M to N is a function f:|M|\to |N| that preserves the interpretation of the operations of T. That is, for each operation symbol f\in \Sigma _T, we have: f_N \circ (f, \cdots , f) = f \circ f_M where f_M and f_N are the interpretations of f in M and N respectively. We say that f is a model isomorphism if it is bijective. We say that M and N are isomorphic if there exists a model isomorphism between them.
We may organize the models of an algebraic theory T into a category \mathbf {Mod}(T) whose objects are the models of the theory and the morphisms are the model homomorphisms.

So far we have considered the models of an algebraic theory as sets with operations. More generally we can consider models in any category C with finite products. Hence the definition of an interpretation and a model may be directly transcribed.

An interpretation I in C is given by
An object |I| in C, called the carrier
For each operation symbol \text {op}_i, a morphism in C [\text {op}_i]_I : |I|^i \to |I| Notice that a nullary symbol is interpreted as a morphism |I|^0 \to |I|, which is a morphism form the terminal object 1\to |I| in C.

Similarly, the interpretation can be extended to terms and equations in the same way. A model of an algebraic theory T in C is an interpretation M of its signature \Sigma _T which validates all the equations E_T. The definition of a homomorphism is now the morphism in the category C. The T\text {-models} and T\text {-homomorphisms} in C form another category, denoted by \mathbf {Mod}_C(T).
Of special interest are the free models of an algebraic theory.

Let T be an algebraic theory and X be a set, the free T-model, also called the free T-algebra, generated by X is a model M together with a map \eta :X\to |M| such that for any T-model L and every map f:X\to |L|, there is a unique T-homomorphism \bar {f}:|M|\to |L| such that the following diagram commutes:
This can be understood as follows: the free T-model generated by X is the most economical way of making a T-model out of the set X. ("Free" essentially means with as few assumptions as possible.)

For instance, the free group generated by the singleton set \{a\} is the infinite cyclic group, which is isomorphic to \mathbb {Z}. If you have an element a, then you automatically have all its powers of a in the group. We can not make any further assumptions because we need to send this free group to any other group that satisfies the group axioms, the powers of a are going to be "interpreted".

Every algebraic theory T has a free model. Given a signature \Sigma and a set X, define \text {Tree}_\Sigma (X) to be the set of well-founded trees built inductively as follows:
\forall x \in X, there is a tree \text {return}(x) \in \text {Tree}_\Sigma (X) (the choice of the label is immaterial in fact)
For each operation symbol \text {op}_i and trees t_1, \cdots , t_{\text {ar}_i} \in \text {Tree}_\Sigma (X), there is a tree, denoted by \text {op}_i(t_1, \cdots , t_{\text {ar}_i}) \in \text {Tree}_\Sigma (X), whose root is labeled by \text {op}_i and whose children are subtrees t_1, \cdots , t_{\text {ar}_i}. In this setting, the \Sigma \text {-terms} in the context x_1, \cdots , x_k are the trees in \text {Tree}_\Sigma (\{x_1, \cdots , x_k\}). A variable x_i is labeled as \text {return}(x_i) when construed as a tree. Suppose x_1, \cdots , x_n \mid t is a term in context and we are given an assignment \sigma : \{x_1, \cdots , x_n\} \to \text {Tree}_\Sigma (X). We can build the tree \sigma (t) inductively as follows:
\sigma (t) = \sigma (x_i) if t = x_i
\sigma (t) = \text {op}_i(\sigma (t_1), \cdots , \sigma (t_{\text {ar}_i})) if t = \text {op}_i(t_1, \cdots , t_{\text {ar}_i}) Briefly, the tree \sigma (t) is obtained by replacing each variable x_i in t with the corresponding tree \sigma (x_i).

Let \sim _T be the least equivalence relation on \text {Tree}_{\Sigma _T}(X) such that:
For every equation x_1, \cdots , x_n \mid l = r in E_T and for every assignment \sigma we have: \sigma (l) \sim _T \sigma (r)
\sim _T is a congruence: for every operation symbol \text {op}_i in \sigma _T and forall trees s_1,\cdot ,s_{\text {ar}_i} and t_1, \cdots , t_{\text {ar}_i} in \text {Tree}_\Sigma (X), if s_1 \sim _T t_1 \quad \cdots \quad s_{\text {ar}_i} \sim _T t_{\text {ar}_i} then the following holds: \text {op}_i(s_1, \cdots , s_{\text {ar}_i}) \sim _T \text {op}_i(t_1, \cdots , t_{\text {ar}_i})

Now we define the carrier the free model F_T(X) to be the quotient set |F_T(X)| = \text {Tree}_{\Sigma _T}(X)/\sim _T Let \langle t \rangle be the \sim _T equivalence class of t \in \text {Tree}_{\Sigma _T}(X), the interpretation of the operation symbol \text {op}_i in the free model is defined by: [\text {op}_i]_{F_T(X)}(\langle t_1 \rangle , \cdots , \langle t_{\text {ar}_i} \rangle ) = \langle \text {op}_i(t_1, \cdots , t_{\text {ar}_i}) \rangle and the map \eta _X : X \to F_T(X) is defined by \eta _X(x) = \langle \text {return}(x) \rangle Note that if theory T has no equations, the free models generated by T is the set of all trees in \text {Tree}_{\Sigma _T}(X) because the equivalence relation \sim _T is the identity relation =.
So far we have developed the algebraic theories, to get a better fit with computational effects, we need to generalize operations in two ways: arities and parameters.

Generalizing arities: One might expect that the generalization of arities is to allow them to be ordinal or cardinal numbers, hence they can fit the infinity. However, that would be a non-computational idea. Instead, we can generalize the arities to be functions. Notice that the n-ary cartesian product of X is isomorphic to the exponential X^{[n]}, where [n] = \{1, \cdots , n\}. Now we replace [n] with arbitrary set A, then we can think of a map X^A \to X as arguments of arity A. We need a reasonable notation for writing down an operation symbol to A\text {-many} arguments, where A is an arbitrary set. To achieve this, we introduce the map \kappa :A\to X, and thus we simply write \text {op}_i(\kappa ) for the operation symbol.
Generalizing parameters: We can generalize operations to take parameters from a set P, this naturally models algebraic operations that arise as computational effects.

Compose them together: Now we can restate the definitions of signatures and algebraic operations with the generalizations incorporated. 649def-004Tdef-004T.xmlParameterized Operations and General AritiesDefinition
A signature \Sigma is given by a collection of operation symbols \text {op}_i with associated parameters sets P_i and arity A_i, denoted \text {op}_i: P_i \rightsquigarrow A_i.
The terms in context are generalized to well-founded trees over \Sigma generated by a set X. These form a set \text {Tree}_\Sigma (X) whose elements are inductively generated:
for every x \in X, there is a tree \text {return}(x) \in \text {Tree}_\Sigma (X)
If p \in P_i and \kappa : A_i \to \text {Tree}_\Sigma (X), then there is a tree \text {op}_i(p, \kappa ) \in \text {Tree}_\Sigma (X), whose root is labeled by \text {op}_i and subtrees are given by the trees in the image of \kappa . The elements of \text {Tree}_\Sigma (X) may be thought of as \Sigma \text {-terms} with variables X.
An interpretation I of a signature \Sigma is given by (here we assume that the category is a category of sets, the more general cases are omitted for brevity):
A set |I| called the carrier of the interpretation
For each operation symbol \text {op}_i: P_i \rightsquigarrow A_i, a map [\text {op}_i]_I : P_i \times |I|^{A_i} \to |I| The interpretation can be extended to terms (trees). A tree t \in \text {Tree}_\Sigma (X) is interpreted as a map [t]_I : |I| ^ X \to |I| as follows:
The tree \text {return}(x) is interpreted as the projection map: [\text {return}(x)]_I : \eta \mapsto \eta (x)
A compound tree is interpreted as the composition of the semantic brackets of the operation symbols and the subtrees: [\text {op}_i(p, \kappa )]_I : \eta \to [\text {op}_i]_I(p, \lambda a. [\kappa (a)]_I(\eta ))
A \Sigma \text {-equation} is a set X and a pair of trees l, r \in \text {Tree}_\Sigma (X): X\mid l = r Given an interpretation I of signature \Sigma , we say that such an equation is valid for I if l and r are interpreted as the same map. The algebraic theory, models and categories are generalized similarly, we do not repeat here.
